course.name: tuxedoUIVisuals
course.title: Reinforcement Course
course.description:
This course will help you master this UI Andromeda and Tuxedo projects! 
We will cover very important material which will make you succeed:
- Visuals (colors, fonts, spacing, responsiveness, etc.)
- Prompt Instruction Following
- Functionality
- Quality Checklist

With a Knowledge Check section!

contents.body:
Purpose of this course:

The purpose of the UI project is to create visually stunning UIs using Next.js and Typescript.


In order to help you create better, more robust, visually stunning UIs, we wanted to share a quick course that goes over some basic UI and project principles.


In this course, we will discuss:

  • Visuals (colors, fonts, spacing, responsiveness, etc.)
  • Prompt Instruction Following
  • Functionality


At the end of this course, you will see a series of questions that you must answer. Please take this course seriously. If you do not pass the quality threshold in the question section, ðŸš¨ðŸš¨ you will not be able to continue on this project ðŸš¨ðŸš¨.

Colors Overview:

Colors can strongly affect how people feel and act. Different colors create different feelings, and these can be influenced by culture and personal experiences. Understanding these color associations can help you design a website that creates the right mood and user experience.


Bad Color Combinations

Bad UI Examples

EXAMPLE # 1: UI LINK

Reasons for fail:

  1. Very hard to read the text of the "New" or "Used - Like New" products. Background overlaps and its very hard to read.
  2. When dark mode is toggled, some text is almost unreadable due to the font color and background.


EXAMPLE # 2: UI LINK

Reasons for fail:

  1. Poor color contrast in dark mode
  2. Light/dark mode not implemented accurately
  3. Not a full UI, just a component. (If it cannot stand alone, not a full UI) It would need at least a landing page explaining the purpose, and some sort of login simulation.



EXAMPLE # 3: UI LINK

Reasons for fail:

  1. Poor color combinations, this does not look professional or up to the Visual Appearance standards we are aiming for.



EXAMPLE # 4: UI LINK

Reasons for fail:

  1. Very poor UI, this does not look professional or up to the Visual Appearance standards we are aiming for.
  2. Very poor color combinations
  3. Typography also looks off.
Good Color Combinations

Good UI Examples

EXAMPLE # 1:  UI LINK 

Reasons:

  1. Great color combinations that are aligned with the theme.
  2. Looks professional and its clearly readable.


EXAMPLE # 2: UI LINK 

Reasons:

  1. Great color combinations that is very attractive and has a great Visual Appearance.
  2. Bold colors, clean, easily readable, and looks professional and related to the theme.

Color Tools

These tools can be helpful when choosing colors:


  • Coolors - Generates color palettes, as well as letting you explore trending color palettes.
  • Code Hex - This color picker will give you the RGB, HSV, and Hex color codes for any color. It also allows you to mix colors.
  • Adobe Color - Generates color palettes, shows trending themes, and allows you to extract themes and gradients for any color based on a provided image.
  • Material UI Colors - Shows a variety of colors and lets you adjust hue and tone to get complementary colors.
  • Brand Colors - Gives the color palettes for some famous brands.
  • Paletton - Allows you to create color palettes based on monochromatic, adjacent, triad, tetrad, and freestyle color themes.

Fonts/Typography Overview:

Typography plays a crucial role in shaping the perception and effectiveness of a website. The choice of typeface, size, spacing, weight, and style can influence readability, brand identity, and user engagement. Different fonts convey various emotions and messages; for example, serif fonts often evoke tradition and reliability, while sans-serif fonts tend to feel modern and approachable. 




Good Font Examples:






These tools can be helpful when choosing fonts:


ï»¿WordMark - Allows you to see how a specific piece of text will look in several different font families.


Typewolf - Shows trending fonts that can be used for different styles and themes.


Google Fonts - Allows you to import and use different fonts in your code project.

Font Examples:


Bad Example #1: UI Link

Explanation: This is a bad example of using fonts because the UI uses the default browser font. You should NEVER use the default browser font. Instead, choose a custom font that is modern, theme-appropriate, and that looks great.


ï»¿



Bad Example #2: UI Link

Explanation: This is a bad example of using fonts because the chosen font doesn't match the theme of the application. The application is a financial and stock dashboard, which should look professional. Using "JetBrains Mono" as the font is probably not the best choice. Instead, a more business-like font should be used.




Good Example #1: UI Link

Example: While this application has some visual issues, it does do a good job of using a font that is appropriate for the theme. The application is a fun coloring tool, so the font is creative and unique, while still being modern and easy to read. It also has good font hierarchy, where titles and more important text are bigger and bolded, while subtext is smaller and has a lower font weight.

Spacing Overview:

Spacing is essential in design as it impacts readability, visual hierarchy, and overall user experience. Proper spacing between letters, words, and lines helps guide the reader's eye and makes content easier to digest. It creates a sense of balance and organization, allowing elements to breathe and enhancing the aesthetic appeal of a website.
Spacing: Do's and Dont's

Example of Bad Spacing:


Example of Good Spacing:

ï»¿



These tools can be helpful when choosing colors:


Figma - A powerful design tool that allows for easy manipulation of spacing and layout, making it ideal for collaborative projects.


Adobe XD - Offers features for designing and prototyping with precise spacing controls, helping to create user-friendly interfaces.


Sketch - A vector-based design tool that helps manage spacing and alignment effectively, perfect for web and mobile design.


Grid Systems - Utilize grid systems like Bootstrap or CSS Grid to maintain consistent spacing across your design, ensuring a cohesive look and feel.

Rules About Styles

Now that you know what we are looking for when it comes to colors, typography, and spacing, there are a few project rules that you should know about.


The purpose of this project is to teach an AI model how to produce visually stunning UIs. This means that producing a variety of UIs is essential. We don't want to see the same colors, fonts, and styles over and over again. We want a range of stunning, professional-looking styles to better train the model.


Follow these rules when working on tasks:

  • Do not use the same colors over and over again. Using a white/gray background with blue buttons looks good, but don't use it over and over again across multiple tasks. Use a wide variety of color palettes.
  • Use different fonts. There are dozens and dozens of professional-looking fonts. We want to train the model to know which fonts are good. Use different fonts across different tasks. Don't use the same 2-3 fonts for every task. NEVER use the browser default font.
  • Do not use the same design across different tasks. Using the same structure for every application, and just changing the colors, fonts, and words is not a productive way to train the model. Be creative. Use a variety of designs and layouts to create visually stunning UIs.


Using the same repeated styles across multiple tasks is grounds for removal from this project!!!

Please review the following common visual errors and do the following:

  1. Understand each error definition
  2. Open the bad example links and identify the corresponding error.
  3. Open the good example links and recognize how the error is fixed.


Responsiveness:

While each task has an assigned priority layout (mobile first, desktop first, etc...), ALL UIs need to be fully responsive. This means that every element, component, piece of text, etc., needs to look good and be functional on all screen sizes (down to 390 px).


ðŸš¨ðŸš¨Reminder!!ðŸš¨ðŸš¨

Test your UIs on ALL screen sizes! If every part of your UI is not fully responsive for desktop, tablet, and mobile screen sizes, your task will FAIL!!


  • Bad Example (click) - This example shows a UI that initially looks pretty good on desktop devices, but when you make the screen smaller, the nav component breaks. The nav menu items don't have enough spacing and since the nav component has a min-width, the layout looks really bad on small screens.



  • Good Example (click) - In this version of the UI, the responsiveness issues are fixed by converting the nav menu items into a hamburger icon with a dropdown menu, and making the nav component resizable. Make sure that every component in your UIs is functional and visually pleasing across all device sizes.

Layout:

The layout of your UI is very important. A good layout will guide the user's eyes to key components and will look balanced and organized. A bad layout will be confusing, jarring, and will cause a bad user experience.


  • Bad Example (click) - In this bad example, you will see that the layout of the page is not very good. The components below the hero section are all stacked on top of each other, there is poor organization, and the design looks unprofessional.



  • Good Example (click) - This good example fixes the layout issues by organizing components nicely and by using vertical and horizontal space well. While your layouts will change based on device screen size, they should always look professional, organized, and well-thought-out.

Font/Typography:

Font and typography used properly can convey organization, meaning, and feeling in your website. Font family, size, weight, and hierarchy an all affect how a website is experienced by a user.


  • Bad Example (click) - In this example, the website fails to properly use font and typography to make the website exceptional. There is no difference in fonts between the important text and the regular body text. Instead, the website looks dull, unorganized, and unprofessional.




  • Good Example (click) - This example shows how the website can be elevated to look much more finished, professional, and organized, just by using font weights, sizes, and hierarchy. Notice how different the website feels with those minor font adjustments.

Buttons/Small Details:

One of the biggest differences between an amazing UI and an average UI is how the small details are treated. An amazing UI will pay attention to the small things to make the site feel much more interactive and professional. A good example of that is how you style the buttons on your website.


  • Bad Example (click) - Notice how the buttons in the hero section are styled in this example. Open the link and interact with those two buttons. How do they look? How does it feel as a user to interact with them?




  • Good Example (click) - Now, open the link to this good example and interact with the same buttons. Which example has a better user experience when interacting with those two buttons? Notice how the padding is better. The corners are rounded. There is a subtle drop shadow. There are hover interactions and animations that weren't present in the bad example. The cursor is now a pointer. Paying attention to those small details makes a world of difference in user experience and UI visuals.

Scroll/Overflow:

A common error that we frequently see is components with content that get cut off and can't be seen by the user. This usually happens when setting a set width or height on a component, and then using the hidden overflow property. Be careful when using this. While a component might be visible to you on a larger screen, a user on a smaller screen might not see all of the content. When there is too much content to fit on the screen, use scrolling to allow the user to access that content. Avoid using horizontal scrolling in most cases.


  • Bad Example (click) - In this example, scroll down to the subscription plan section and select the basic plan. You will see that the component cuts off some of the content on the bottom. This looks bad and leads to a poor user experience.



  • Good Example (click) - In this good example, the component is sized properly so that all content can be seen. Be careful about using set sizes, or sizes based on screen size, in conjunction with the hidden overflow property. Make sure that all of your UI's content can be seen on all device sizes.

Spacing/Alignment:

Make sure that you use good spacing and alignment when creating your UIs. An application that doesn't have enough spacing will look cluttered and unorganized. An application with too much spacing looks bare and unfinished. Also, make sure that you use good alignment. An application should feel balanced and uniform.


  • Bad Example (click) - In this bad example, you will notice that the header component is not aligned properly, and the header menu items have poor spacing. The buttons in the hero section have no spacing between them, which makes the page feel cluttered. Also, if you scroll to the bottom, you will see that the form has poor spacing as well. This makes the application feel unbalanced, and doesn't look good.



  • Good Example (click) - In this good example, the header is aligned, with sufficient space between the menu items. The buttons in the hero section are slightly separated, and the form at the bottom of the page looks much better. This is all due to spacing and alignment.

The prompt is one of the most important parts of the task. It gives instructions for what should be included in the UI and how it should be implemented. Remember, we are training an LLM to create UIs based on a user's prompt, so it is very important that we teach the LLM the importance of strictly following the prompt requests and guidelines.


An error that frequently causes tasks to fail is UIs that do not FULLY follow the prompt. Every single explicit and implicit request, requirement, and guideline needs to be completely and accurately implemented. Do not take creative liberties that deviate from what the prompt states.


Read the following prompt and then open the UI link below. Determine if the UI fully fulfills all prompt requirements.


Example #1: UI Link


Prompt: "I am the head of an architecture design firm and I want you to create a website for me using Next.js and Typescript. The website should have a menu at the top with links to sections called Home, Our Projects, Our Team, Reviews, and Contact Us. Below the menu there should be a nice big section with a photo carousel that loops through different pictures. Then, below that the sections from the menu should be added, like Our Projects, Our Team, etc. Be sure to add a contact form in the Contact Us section. Return the code in a single .tsx file."


Explanation: The UI fails to fully meet the prompt requirements because the prompt requested specific names for the menu links, but the UI uses different names. For example, the prompt asked for a menu link called "Our Projects", but the actual implementation just calls it "Projects". Even minor deviations from the prompt, like this one, are bad and constitute a failing UI.


ï»¿



Example #2: UI Link


Prompt: "I am building a subscription marketplace for SaaS products to help users compare tools and choose the right plan more easily. Users should be able to add and see customer review ratings for each tool. The interface should be built using Next.js and Typescript. I want to include a grid of product cards with pricing tiers. There should also be feature comparison tables and a sticky checkout sidebar that stays visible as users scroll. The app should support dynamic currency conversion, a toggle for switching between monthly and annual pricing, and payment modals. The design should follow a clean, modern aesthetic with smooth shadows and well-spaced elements. Provide the entire implementation as a single, self-contained TSX file."


Explanation: The UI fails to fully meet the prompt requirements because the prompt says that the user should be able to ADD and see review ratings. While the application lets users see the ratings, it fails to implement the functionality to let users add their own review ratings.


ï»¿

Functionality Overview

The UIs that you are building on this project need to be fully functional. We are not looking for demo applications, or apps that are "under construction". We are looking for high-quality, production-ready applications that are fully functional.


In other words, every single feature that you include in a UI needs to be fully functional. If you include a like button, then that like button needs to work. If you include a search bar, then that search logic needs to be implemented. Every feature needs to be fully functional, and needs to function accurately.


Fake Functionality

Having said that, you are only working with front end technologies. This means that many times you will need to create mock functionality and use mock data in order for all of your features to be fully functional.


For example, if you are adding a login button to your UI, then the user should be able to click on that button, see a login form, and be able to enter a username and password to "login" to the site. You won't actually need to create a backend to verify their inputs, but instead you can allow any combination of inputs to allow the user to "login".


To give another example, if the prompt asks for a data dashboard, you won't actually connect to a database or API to pull that data in, but instead you can use fake data structured as an object, or something like that.


Warnings

Any features that are included in the UI that are not functional, or that do not function properly, will cause your task to fail.

NEVER include "coming soon" or "under construction" features.


Example # 1

Prompt:

I am the coordinator of the group for a big trip with my friends, and I need help creating a messaging app for my friend group where we can plan and coordinate among us. I'd like a clean design with a sidebar showing who's online, a main chat area, and a way to send messages. Nothing too fancy, but it should look modern and work on phones too. Build me a group chat UI where we can share messages and maybe even photos, using Next.js and Typescript in a single .tsx file.

UI LINK


Functionality issue: In this messaging app, when you send a message to someone, you can see that that person will be "Typing" back to respond, but once you switch to a chat with another person, this "typing" will get carried over into the new chat with a different person. Itâ€™s a functionality that is included, but itâ€™s buggy, and therefore a quality failure.


.



Example # 2

Prompt:

Create a music player application where users can listen to music, add their favorite tracks to their wishlist, view lyrics, and play songs on loop using Next.js and Typescript. Provide me a single, self-contained .tsx file that contains everything needed for the setup with no additional requirements.

UI LINK


Functionality issue: First song in the playlist plays an audio, the rest don't play any audio.

When doing a task, always use the following Quality Checklist.

This will help you avoid any quality mistakes.


Quality Checklist.


1. Prompt Understanding

  • Did I read the prompt carefully and understand the requirements?
  • Did I identify all explicit and essential implicit features?

2. Visual Appearance

  • Is the UI modern and clean?
  • Is it responsive across desktop and mobile (resize to test)?
  • Are fonts, colors, and spacing consistent?
  • Is the layout well-organized with a clear visual hierarchy?
  • Are there visual glitches or broken rendering?
  • Is the design production-ready or teaching-level?

3. Functionality

  • Is there any missing core functionality?
  • Do all primary user flows work end to end?
  • Are edge-case inputs handled gracefully?

4. Explicit Instruction Following

  • Are all required features in the prompt implemented?

5. Code Quality

  • Does the code run without errors?
  • Is the code well-structured, readable, and maintainable?
  • Are comments accurate (no misleading or incorrect ones)?

How To Ensure Your Response Satisfies All Prompt Requirements?

Use our Vercel app! Vercel Prompt Rubric Generator


Ingest your prompt, and get rubrics to verify all requests are covered!


Prompt sample:

I am looking for a mobile dashboard for tracking my fitness routine. Each activity should appear as a card with a video thumbnail on the front.

When I swipe the card, it should flip to show an interactive map and a graph with my route and biometrics.

Make it with a semi-flat, modern design with emerald green and rose color palette.

Use Next.js with TailwindCSS, and keep it all in a single self-contained TSX page file with a default export.


Objective:

Once you go through a task, always use this and check all the requirements that are fulfilled. You should go through each of this steps in the UI and test all the explicit AND implicit requirements,

contents.question:
Which font would you choose for a healthcare website?


A) Comic Sans: a playful and casual font


B) Open Sans: a clean and modern font


C) Curlz: a decorative and ornate font


D) Papyrus: a unique and exotic font

ï»¿

choices.answer: A) Comic Sans: a playful and casual font
B) Open Sans: a clean and modern font
C) Curlz: a decorative and ornate font
D) Papyrus: a unique and exotic font

contents.question:
Open the following UI link and review the application. Select ALL visual error categories that are present in this application.


UI Link

Read the prompt, open the following UI link and review the missing features which were requested. (Instruction Following)


Build a grocery ordering platform using Next.js and Typescript, where users will be able to view groceries, add to cart, and place an order. They need to be able to filter by the following categories: Fresh Produce, Dairy & Eggs, Meats & Seafood, Bakery, Beverages. When products are on discount, the original price should be crossed out, and the new price should be in read next to it. The UI should be appealing, and the implementation should provide a single, self-contained .tsx file that contains everything needed for the UI.

UI LINK


Question:

What features are missed or are incomplete in this UI, that were explicitly mentioned in the prompt?

choices.answer: The response allows users to add groceries to the cart
The response provides filtering for Fresh Produce, Dairy & Eggs, Meats & Seafood, Bakery, and Beverages
The response displays the new discounted price in red next to the original price
The response allows users to view groceries
The response allows users to place orders
The response ensures the UI is appealing

contents.hint: There's 2 features which are not implemented! Remember the examples on Instruction following
contents.explanation: Correct! Meats & Seafood is missing, even when explicitly mentioned, and the discount feature is not implemented!

contents.question:
Read the prompt, open the following UI link and review the features functionality to identify any issues. (Functionality)


I want to create a clean and contemporary blog site. The main page should display a collection of article cards, each showing a thumbnail and a brief snippet. Users can click the thumbnail and snippet to read the full article on its own dedicated page. I would also like a simple responsive navigation bar for easy site exploration. Please ensure the overall design uses classy typography and a professional feel.


UI LINK

Question:

Test ALL functionalities and mark the ones that are not working as expected.
contents.hint: Remember to test ALL functionalities, and select ALL of them
contents.explanation: Correct! There's multiple issues! 1. The thumbnail does not work, it doesnt lead you to the post. 2. The like button does not work 3. Filters are not working
